comments.commentBody:
Thank you Mr Kristof for trying to build bridges when people are in a mood to burn them down.
Nighat

Are you also appalled when the American left labels Haitian aid workers as "Tali-Baptists". The demagoguery against Muslims is shameful, but the American left seems to think that hate speech against Christians is just fine, thank you.

If Imam Rauf is an example of a moderate Islam, a man who can't bring himself to call Hamas a terrorist group, and who insensitively denounces those who are upset about a mosque in the area of ground zero, well that just doesn't do it for me. It sounds like you are among those, like President Obama, who feels if you show you them you are on their side, they'll like you better. Maybe not all Muslims are terrorists, but I still can't get images out of my head from the Arab world handing out candy in celebration when the Twin Towers were attacked. I am sure no one would consider those celebrants your typical terrorist--but don't think they they don't sympathize with them or value martydom. Your groveling apology borders on the pathetic.

Dont blame the negative stereotyping of Moslems by Americans.

I do not recall a mass organized protest by American Moslems against the 9/11 attack. I do not recall any mass organized protest by American Moslems against any terrorist attack conducted by Muslims.
The radical muslims have publicly defamed their religion. It is up to the moderate American Moslem community to publicly reposses their religion back by mass organized protests which publicly condemn what their radical brothers are doing around the world - killing in the name of Allah and trying to make shariah law universal. They cannot blame the many Americans who stereotype them negatively because of their passivity.

I thank Mr. Kristof for writing this article. I myself am a Muslim who lived most of his adult life in the US. I worked hard, got advanced degree from one of the most prestigious universities in the country. My household income is high enough that we can afford residences in several countries.
My wife almost got killed during 9/11; I organised a blood drive shortly after that and volunteered. I have been a bone marrow donor long before any Muslims attacked the United States; I certainly hope my actions helped save at least one American life.

These days, I find it terribly disturbing when a mainstream leader such as Newt Gringrich, just to improve his dismal approval ratings by few points, categorically lump all Muslims as terrorists or terrorist sympathizers. These shallow leaders all claim to be Reagan Republicans; but they are nothing but..And frankly I am alarmed by how few narrow minded people are transforming my beloved America into a place that would shock the founding fathers.

I am considering raising my children outside of the United States. My family is welcome in any country of the world; why should I subject my children to these anti-Muslim rhetoric as they grow up?

Not bad, except where you characterized the "suggestion" that moderate muslims apologize for the acton of their brethren as "reasonable". (Read it, you did. Maybe an editing error?)

On what basis is that reasonable? Some kind of distributed sin? Should I apologize for the sins of all geeks?

Other than that, I liked the essay.

Americans should stand up for Muslims in this country if only so we can retain our self respect. If two-thirds of all Muslims were genuinely evil, non-Muslims would still be wrong to blame the other third. Innocent until proven guilty is not merely a legal ideal, it is the only thing that makes the least bit of sense.

I am so sick of hearing Muslims being held guilty until that have sufficiently proven themselves to be innocent. And for those who think that the members of any ethnic or religious or other group should be denied equal rights and liberties, as many would now deny Muslims their legal right to build a mosque on land where a different owner would be welcome to build a church, I ask a simple question:

If I assume you are a thief, because in my experience thieves generally look like you, and I believe that if it walks like a duck ... etc., then tell me:

How exactly are you going to PROVE that you have never stolen anything? By loudly denouncing theft as a bad thing?

The burden of proof MUST fall to party who asserts a fact, never to the party who denies it.

Prove someone has broken a law, and throw him in jail. If you can't prove that he has, then leave him alone. His membership in a group has nothing to do with it.

Not all Germans were responsible for the Holocaust, no matter how many were.

Holding an entire group responsible for the wicked actions of some, or even most, of its members is just plain stupid, just plain wrong.

It is wrong when anyone does it.

Many bad things are done by people who happen to be Muslims. And those individuals deserve blame. But not their brothers, sisters, aunts, or uncles, unless they aided or abetted the wrongdoers.

Penalizing "Muslims" just for being Muslims is no different than penalizing you because one of your relatives committed a crime.

Dear Mr Kristof,

You made me cry.
Its absolutely disgusting and insane.

Its antisemitic. (Semites being those from the lands in the middle east)
I am appalled by the retrograde shameful, nutty, slanderous, intolerant, bigoted, idiotic, cruel nastiness of tarring one of the great religions of the world, and all those who belong to it, with the actions of a few extremists.

Have we learned nothing from history.
Are we returning to dark ages of stupidity.

I applaud you Mr Kristof for you apology. And i add mine.

It's socially acceptable to be openly hostile and discriminatory to atheists and agnostics as well (most of whom are 'in the closet', and NO ONE ever apologizes or cares about it.  In fact, I've heard comments to the fact that Muslims are OK because at least they believe in God (unlike the unspeakable American Citizens who cannot profess any belief in supernatural powers).

This entire year has been trying for me. For the first time, I no longer feel welcome in my own country, despite the fact that I served her in the U.S. Military (I even earned a GWOT for my service in OEF). Yet because I'm a Muslim -- and it's easy to tell because I wear a head scarf -- suddenly I am being yelled at and told to "go to your own country". This IS my country, and the country of my parents, and my grandparents. Some of my ancestors were here before Columbus, even. And unlike many other Americans, I volunteered to protect my country and the Constitution. But none of that matters now because I am "the enemy".

I sincerely thank you for this article.

Wonderful column.  I'd go one more step, though:  These people like Terry Jones, Newt Gingrich, Glenn Beck--they're not just nutty, they're downright dangerous.  And I think also cynical and hypocritical--I mean, come on, a supposed 'Christian' and 'minister' like Terry Jones bashing another religion is not too Christian-like.  And Newt Gingrich--just when you thought there was someone on the right who had a brain, he shows his true colors.  And I don't know what to make about Glenn Beck--clearly he's not stupid, so I guess he's just an opportunist trying to dupe the poor idiots who salivate over his every word and make as much money as possible,  It's a pretty sick time in our country's history, and these people certainly are not patriots.

Thank you for a reasoned moment of sanity amid the clatter of hysteria from the uninformable groundlings. The arrogance of the ignorant is loud, but empty ... and based upon the fear that the rest of us might figure out that they're nothing more than the school-yard bullies grown up. Religuous fanatics are the same everywhere: "over there" they're called 'The Taliban'..."over here" they're called "The Religuous Right." God does not speak through the ignorant. And God may be running out of patience with the presumption of the yappers.

I want to express my gratitude to you for writing this article.  Would you please have someone at the L.A. Times do the same?  There are just too many right wing extremists who know absolutely nothing about Muslims or their core beliefs and are spewing hatred and fear (like Rush L. and FOX News) to Americans (I guess they learned this from Karl Rove).  I want to thank you for your sanity and compassion for all people.  I saw a wonderful bumper sticker the other day that says it all - "GOD SO LOVED THE WORLD - NO EXCEPTIONS."

Disappointingly, some commentators are still blowing the same anti-Islamic smoke out their nostrils - with the same psuedo-scholarly criticism of the religion.  We might do well to remember that Islam is 1500 years old and Christianity is 2000.  Five hundred years ago the peace loving harmonious Christians we know today were burning each other alive and pulling each other apart on racks by the tens of thousands.  I wonder if we stop providing the Muslim world with the distraction of a common enemy they might resolve some of the issues these people are attacking them for on their own.  As you've seen Mr. Kristof, many have the will to do so.

Very good article!

Stephen 322, you wrote: "And there's a huge difference between an act of war and a act of terrorism."

That's so true. Please tell the people at Guantanamo running the trial of Omar Khadr who is called a "terrorist" by the US government and is charged with "war crimes" that don't exist under international law, solely for having fought the US after it invaded the country he was living in.

So another apologist for America when none is needed.
Perhaps Obama's Apology Tour has sparked an imitator in Mr. Kristof.

New Yorkers were justifiably offended by the announced intentions to muzzle a mosque up to Ground Zero, and they neither need nor want anyone else being so presumptuous as to apologize for their feelings.

Mr. Kristof asks to accept a burden which has not been offered to him and it's vainglorious and conceited of him to try to shoulder it.
If he feels guilt for his own actions, let him make his own amends.
Otherwise, hands off the justifiable opinions of others.

It is a very curious thing that so many people forget the genocide of the Native Americans in this country and elsewhere in the Americas by "good" Christians. Of course, we should also recall the tremendous loss of life that resulted from slavery as mentioned in other comments. More recently, the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan have killed hundreds of thousands of innocents in those countries, a fact that gets little mention in the mainstream press. The reference that no Catholics had killed thousands of people in the US prompts this question: Why did the killing of 168 people and hundreds more who were injured by a Catholic McVeigh in Oklahoma City not trigger a similar widespread anger toward, and suspicion of, Catholics? The answer, I think, is fairly straightforward and lies in the easy demonization of a group that is not considered to be an intrinsic part of American life. But viewing major events and crises through a narrow, historical lens obscures the injustices and tragedies of the past. We should instead keep these in view so that we may better understand the roots and origins of intolerance, fear and violence. We may then be able to move more positively toward building bridges and a more just, tolerant and compassionate world for our children and grandchildren. This is, at the end of the day, what most of humanity, regardless of faith or religion, seeks.

Thank you for serving as a clear mirror to the energies of intolerance that are running high-- and for tracking these across time and place. In times of uncertainty, it is easy to look for an enemy, to project our collective shadow so that we do not have to be vulnerable or own our own pain.

That has been the same in the rise of the Know- Nothing Party, the Klan in Reconstructionist South, the trajectory of Weimar Germany, the internment of Japanese and German Americans-- and as you know, too many other times and places. Seeing the patterns we can become a little bit more free.

Mr. Kristof,

Among other things, you wrote: "Muslims are one of the last minorities in the United States that it is still possible to demean openly."

Actually, I think it's quite the opposite. A wave of political correctness (enforced by death threats from the radical fringe of Islam, and dutifully relayed by the highest echelons of our government) has stifled free speech where it relates to that religion, working to insulate it from the insults to which Christianity and Judaism have long been subject in this country.

For as long as I can recall, Christians and Jews have had to take gut punches from seemingly every quarter, including Hollywood, the artistic community, outspoken atheists, and the news media -- all in the interest of "artistic license," intellectual fashion and, of course, general free speech. Suffer these we surely have, sometimes under protest, but always peacefully and with an understanding of the benefits and burdens of free speech. The Last Temptation of Christ, Salieri's fireplace burning of a crucifix in Amadeus, and Serrano's "P*ss Christ" come immediately to mind, and there are countless other examples as I'm sure you well know. The disparate treatment of Christianity and Judaism on the one hand, and Islam on the other, is at least partially accounted for by the fact that Hollywood has never been threatened with obliteration by a Christian mob, and no "blasphemer" against Christianity has ever had to go into FBI protective custody under threat of fatwa. Nor should they be.

As one of this nation's core values, the constitutional right to free speech, and perhaps especially to offensive free speech (since inoffensive speech needs no constitutional protection), must be defended at all costs. Constitutionally protected free speech includes the right to express hatred, as long as the expression does not include or imply a threat. On the other hand, there is no constitutional right not to have your feelings hurt. This means that, in the United States, one is legally permitted to demean Islam, burn Korans, draw Mohammed, and so on, without fear of violent retribution. Personally, I understand and agree that such acts are offensive, and sympathize with those who are offended. I myself would not do these things, but in this country even the hateful and the offensive have a right to speak. The best response is to refrain from giving them an audience.

Thank you, Nicholas Kristof, for your message of clarity and tolerance. I think that your words were something that many Muslims, in other countries as well as in America, needed to hear, and I applaud you on setting such an excellent example of tolerance for all people, Muslims included.
As a Muslim, I apologize for the acts of extremist Muslims, and I would like to inform those who do not yet know that Islam is a religion of peace and tolerance, not what is represented by extremist groups that claim to be Muslim, such as the Taliban.
Again, thank you, Nicholas Kristof.

I think your article is too simplistic... I find it hard to belive that anybody who says "all muslims are terrorists" will be taken seriously in the US. That kind of generalization would be a stupid thing to say. The people who do say such things are in such a minority that you just ignore them ... similar to the number of moderate muslims in the world that are ignored by their more narrow minded muslim berthren.
Thank you.  Hate breeds nothing but more hate.  Hate breeds on ignorance.

Christians, Muslims & Jews all share a common heritage. Yet adherents from each religion not only have extremists who "believe" the other two faiths are no more than infidels who deserve to die; but have the same intense hatred for other members within their own religious umbrella who don't conform to their narrow view of their faith's aspirations.
We all can benefit from coming to the realization that we (Jews, Muslims & Christians) all have more in common than our differences. In the true spirit of fellowship & understanding, each of us must first purge our own personal demons, instead of lashing out at others. The act of lashing out is in itself giving in to our demons & denying the common ideal to "love thy neighbor as thyself".
The Holist Day of the Jew Calender, Yom Kippur & Islam's Holy Month of Ramadan have just ended. Both uphold the concept to cleans oneself of our sins.
In Judaism, Yom Kippur is the culmination of the period called the "Ten Days of Repentance"; during which along with praying to G-d for forgiveness, we are reminded to apology directly to those we have personally offended. It is only through our own humility & acknowledgement of our capacity to harm, even if only by words; that we can begin the long difficult & necessary process of healing the wounds we've committed.
It is my hope that good people of all of our faiths can put aside our own pride & embrace the idea the we alone can reverse the hatred in the world by making amends with those we've offended. Further I hope that those we apologize to, will see fit to not only accept it; but at the same time search their own souls to apologize in kind. We can still have our differences, but we don't have to hate because of them!
Joe Torre is RETIRING. Why all this speculation about nothing?
